page.title: 08Rubery in the early 1900's
page.content: The motor era was just beginning.White and Pikes printing works at Longbridge closed down and the derelict site was bought by Herbert Austin. The first car took a year to produce and was tested by Austin himself on the Lickey Hills in 1906. Rubery had grown from a few cottages to 146 houses, for apart from the Motor Works there were Quarries,the Asylum, and now two brickworks. There was a mineral water factory owned by Sidney Lander,later taken over by Saxons on the site of the now "Hawthorns Social Club" During the war the Austin Motor Co. made munitions:8 million sheets, 650 guns, 2000 aeroplanes, 2,500 aero engines and 2,000 trucks. Rubery Hill Hospital became a military hospital ,and most homes took in relatives of the wounded soldiers.
